2.  [build\_runner](https://dart.dev/tools/build_runner)
# build\_runner
A tool for building, testing, and running Dart code.
more\_vert
-   copyCopy link
-   [docsView source](https://github.com/dart-lang/site-www/blob/main/src/content/tools/build_runner.md)
-   [bug\_reportReport issue](https://github.com/dart-lang/site-www/issues/new?template=1_page_issue.yml&page-url=https://dart.dev/tools/build_runner&page-source=https://github.com/dart-lang/site-www/blob/main/src/content/tools/build_runner.md)
The [build\_runner](https://pub.dev/packages/build_runner) package provides general-purpose commands for generating files, including testing the generated files or serving both source and generated files. This page explains how to use `build_runner`. To learn how to use build\_runner with a specific package, see the documentation for that package.
infoNote
If you're a web developer, use the [`webdev` tool](https://dart.dev/tools/webdev) to build and serve web apps.
The build\_runner commands work with _builders_—packages that use the [Dart build system](https://github.com/dart-lang/build) to generate output files from input files. For example, the [json\_serializable](https://pub.dev/packages/json_serializable) and [built\_value\_generator](https://pub.dev/packages/built_value_generator) packages define builders that generate Dart code.
Although the Dart build system is a good alternative to reflection (which has performance issues) and macros (which Dart's compilers don't support), it can do more than just read and write Dart code. For example, the [sass\_builder](https://pub.dev/packages/sass_builder) package implements a builder that generates `.css` files from `.scss` and `.sass` files.
## Setting up build\_runner
[#](#setting-up-build_runner)
To use build\_runner, add a [dev dependency](https://dart.dev/tools/pub/dependencies#dev-dependencies) on **build\_runner** to your app's pubspec:
yaml
```
dev_dependencies:
  # ···
  build_runner: ^2.10.4
  build_test: ^3.5.4
```
content\_copy
Depending on **build\_test** is optional; do it if you'll be testing your code.
As usual after `pubspec.yaml` changes, run `dart pub get` or `dart pub upgrade`:
```
$ dart pub get
```
content\_copy
## Using built-in commands
[#](#using-built-in-commands)
The following is an example of using the build\_runner **build** command:
```
$ # From a directory that contains a pubspec.yaml file:
$ dart run build_runner build
```
content\_copy
The build\_runner package includes the following commands:
build
Performs a one-time build.
serve
Runs a development server. Instead of directly using this command, you can use [`webdev serve`,](https://dart.dev/tools/webdev#serve) which has convenient default behavior.
test
Runs [tests.](https://dart.dev/tools/testing)
watch
Launches a build server that watches for edits to input files. Responds to changes by performing incremental rebuilds.
## More information
[#](#more-information)
-   [webdev](https://dart.dev/tools/webdev) guide (use if you're working on web-specific code)
-   [build\_runner](https://pub.dev/packages/build_runner) guide
-   [packages with the `build_runner` dependency](https://pub.dev/packages?q=dependency%3Abuild_runner)
-   [packages with the `build` dependency](https://pub.dev/packages?q=dependency%3Abuild)
